Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story: I sat at the small desk in the ambulance station, my phone buzzing with new emails from my team at the office. They needed my input on a project, and the last message was clear: “We can’t move forward until you clarify this point.” I knew they were waiting, probably watching the inbox, expecting a quick reply so the work could continue. I started typing a response, trying to focus, but my radio crackled to life, the dispatcher’s voice sharp and urgent, “Unit 3, stand by for possible cardiac arrest call.” My heart raced. As an ambulance driver, I had to be ready to jump into action at a moment’s notice—lives depended on it. But as a colleague, I was expected to be present, responsive, and reliable for my team. I stared at the half-written email, my fingers frozen above the keyboard, torn between the responsibility to my coworkers and the duty to the next emergency. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, and I felt the tension rising as I waited for the next call or the next message, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
